legalStatus.loanTypeAllowed: Title Loans (Regulated under California Financing Law)
legalStatus.restrictions: Subject to California Financing Law; Must be licensed by DFPI
legalStatus.notes: California allows title loans but has strict consumer protections. For loans under $2,500, rates are capped. For loans $2,500+, there is NO APR cap, resulting in typical rates of 90-180% APR.

regulations.maxLoanAmount: No state limit (typically $2,500-$10,000 depending on license type)
regulations.maxAPR: Under $2,500: 12-30% depending on principal amount; $2,500+: NO CAP (typically 90-180% APR)
regulations.coolingOffPeriod: 2 business days (right to rescind certain loans)
regulations.loanToValueRatio: Typically 50% of wholesale vehicle value (industry practice, not statutory)

fees.maxOriginationFee: For loans under $2,500: Lesser of 5% of principal or $50; For $2,500+: No cap but must be disclosed
fees.otherFees: Administrative fees and charges must be fully disclosed; For loans $2,500+, fees generally uncapped

licensing.regulatoryBody: Department of Financial Protection and Innovation (DFPI)
licensing.notes: Principals cannot have criminal history or non-compliance with regulatory requirements

rightToRescind.notes: Borrower can cancel certain loans within 2 business days of signing without penalty

requiredDisclosures: Total dollar cost of loan (principal + interest + fees)
Statement about early payoff benefits and no prepayment penalty
Statement about right to rescind (where applicable)
License number and DFPI contact information

disclosureRequirements.languageRequirement: Must be in the language in which loan was negotiated
disclosureRequirements.timing: At time of application, before signing

prohibitedPractices: Charging more than legal limits (for loans under $2,500)

collectionRules.repossessionNotice: Notice of Seizure within 48 hours of repossession
collectionRules.noticeBeforeSale: At least 15 days written notice before vehicle auction
collectionRules.personalPropertyRights: Borrower has 60 days to retrieve personal items from vehicle
collectionRules.deficiencyBalance: Lender can pursue deficiency judgment after vehicle sale
collectionRules.gracePeriod: No legally required grace period before repossession
collectionRules.peacefulRepossession: Repo agents cannot breach the peace or enter locked property without permission

remoteShutdownDevices.notes: Lenders may use remote engine shutdown devices and GPS tracking but must disclose this

consumerProtections.fairDealingRequirement: Even when interest rates are not capped, lenders must deal fairly and honestly with borrowers

recentChanges.change: SB 318 established Pilot Program for Increased Access to Responsible Small Dollar Loans
SB 1146 created Pilot Program for Affordable Credit-Building Opportunities

cityPageContent.headline: Understanding Title Loan Laws in California
cityPageContent.intro: Residents of {{city}} are protected by California's consumer lending regulations administered by the Department of Financial Protection and Innovation (DFPI).
keyPoints: California allows title loans through licensed lenders under the California Financing Law
For loans under $2,500, interest rates are capped at 12-30% depending on loan amount
For loans $2,500 and above (nearly all title loans), there is NO state APR cap - rates typically range from 90-180% APR or higher
All lenders must be licensed by DFPI - verify at portal.dfpi.ca.gov before signing
You have the right to full disclosure of all costs in clear 12-point font or larger
You have the right to pay off your loan early without penalty, reducing interest costs
If your vehicle is repossessed, you must receive written notice and have 15 days before the lender can sell it
You have 60 days to retrieve personal items from your repossessed vehicle
DFPI warns: Title loans should be a LAST RESORT option - explore alternatives first
warnings: WARNING: For almost all auto title loans in California, the interest rate can be extremely high (90-180% APR or more) because loans are typically made for $2,500 or more, which have no interest rate cap
Few assets are more important to your financial security than your car - you risk losing it if you default
Consider alternatives: employer paycheck advance, credit union short-term loan, asking creditors for more time, borrowing from family
cityPageContent.disclaimer: This information is for general guidance only and may not reflect the most current legal developments. California title loans are regulated by the Department of Financial Protection and Innovation (DFPI) under the California Financing Law. Laws and regulations change frequently. DFPI strongly urges consumers to exercise great care before taking out an auto title loan and to try other options first. This should be considered a loan product of last resort. Consult with a licensed attorney or contact DFPI at dfpi.ca.gov for the most accurate and up-to-date information.
